conversations.session_notes:
I just realized that two somewhat central things to look for in dialogue in general would be how they relate to content creation and production, if they do it themselves, if they enjoy it and think they can do it well and with reliability, even concepts that may be a bit harder. If they don't produce it themselves, the equation changes. But if they do it themselves, then it will be useful to get a sense of how adaptable and willing to face editing/complex camera work is. Some concepts have higher or lower "replicability", which would usually include (are there many shots or complex editing work included, does the script need more that 2+ participants? the less the better, is there enough room or willingness to shoot within the premise, especially if it's complex or requires more time? how willing is the person to make the shooting work, overcome low replicability)

The second thing would be brand tone, and what is steered away from in terms of message or other. This is alluded to in many instances, but there isn't too much questioning (what is the target audience, are there any themes that are no go? adult or suggestive content? Edgy ok? And in that case, where does that line go). One would assume that the lines are drawn similarily for many, but questioning can be developed for this.

messages.content: I'm here to understand your content voice and positioning. What does your Brooklyn Burger feed actually look like right now—can you describe your last 3-4 posts?
This is one of my latest posts: https://www.tiktok.com/@brooklynburger.se/video/7504954839323938070

I can see this video uses workplace comedy with a language barrier twist—pretty high production value with the skit format. The humor comes from the fake choice setup and the Swedish/English dynamic.

Is this representative of your typical content style, or was this more of a one-off experiment? And who's behind creating these—is it you personally or do you have a content team?
https://www.tiktok.com/@brooklynburger.se/video/7553618259438816534

Got it. So you're consistently doing these workplace/restaurant skits with that slightly annoyed, relatable energy. Both videos have that same POV format where the viewer is experiencing the frustration alongside you.

Who's the creative force behind these—are you writing and performing these yourself, or is there a team involved? And what made you land on this specific style of workplace comedy for Brooklyn Burger?
https://www.tiktok.com/@brooklynburger.se/video/7501728303523351830

Alright, I'm seeing the pattern now. You've got this consistent workplace comedy voice—the frustrated employee dealing with annoying customers, language barriers, and then celebrating when the boss leaves. It's all very relatable, slightly sarcastic energy with good production quality.

So who's actually creating these? Are you the one writing and performing, or is there someone on your team handling the content strategy and execution?

Sometimes it's workplace comedy, but we also do simple videos showing the food and asking if they would eat it, or showing new items etc. Simple content and not just sketches. We create these in house, but we draw inspiration from other similar brands to how they form their content strategy. I am one in the team that handle content sometimes, but I don't have the ultimate responsibility.

So you're part of the content team but not the lead—got it. When you say you draw inspiration from similar brands, which ones are you actually looking at? And when you create those simpler food showcase videos versus the workplace skits, what drives that decision—is it just variety or are you targeting different outcomes?

notable_quotes: we draw inspiration from other similar brands
I don't have the ultimate responsibility

messages.content: We want variety. We don't want to give the impression that we are strictly a funny video page, but rather that we can do that and that it's enjoyable, but we have a business first and foremost.

Makes sense—you're balancing entertainment with business credibility. When you do create the workplace comedy content, why that specific frustrated employee angle? Is that just what feels natural to your team, or did you test different comedy styles and find this one worked best for your audience?

messages.content: Hm...not quite. Yes, we try to go for something balanced, but in relation to other channels I would say that we have a distinct style that combines cool with edgy humour that still feels playful and inclusive. We value good looking content that engage, and are willing to do fun but clever comedy sketches. But usually we do simpler sketches for simplicity. Regarding the sweet spot, we don't only go for frustrated employee energy. Those happened to be the two clips you saw. But absurdist humor yes, and also staying relatable. But we are a young team catering to youth, so it's not really about staying "relatable", unless you mean that a rigid enough brand could be perceived to be non personal. In that case, yes.

You're right, I was too narrow on the frustrated employee thing—that was just what those specific videos showed. So you're more about cool-meets-edgy humor that's still inclusive, with good production values. When you say "clever comedy sketches," what does clever look like for you? And since you mentioned other channels—who are you actually drawing inspiration from in terms of that cool/edgy balance?

messages.content: I'm here to understand your content voice so we can match you with concepts that actually fit. What does your Café Bambi feed look like right now—describe your last few posts.

I do content for Café Bambi, but it can almost be perceived like a personal brand set in Café Bambi. Most of my uploads are café related scenarios/meme formats, with me as the main character but sometimes also my colleagues included. I'm a young brunette barista, and the posts I upload usually (not always) has this quick form POV format. The clip is usually 5-15 second long, with a text overlay establishing the premise, and me playing out a funny and sometimes self-depricating sketch or concept. Examples could be me gossiping with my colleagues, taking on a customer in an unexpected way, insinuating that I'm tired of work etc. Stuff that is relatable for young people, but maybe girls more, and is still in "fantasy land", clearly a humorous page. I get a lot of views and likes, and try to keep my page very well maintained (high quality recording, editing, acting)

So you've built a character-driven brand where you're essentially the face of Café Bambi through relatable workplace comedy. The POV format with text overlays suggests you understand what performs on TikTok.

What made you choose this approach over showcasing the café itself—the coffee, the space, typical café content?

conversations.session_notes:
I think the conversation is more focused, but it follows a structure where someone is guiding for business purposes, which isn't the goal exactly. The real goal is to actually end the conversation. To cover the important questions in an organic way, where the goal is to ask and get a sense of the core tone/voice, which is not a set metric or value but an evolving self-feeding cultural agreement within the owners experience and what is manifested out there. The tone/voice is what the content agent (the person responsible for the content of a business) is able to produce within the scope of his/her creativity, opportunity and time. The feeling or overall message (how the content blends together into a cohesive message) is the ever-evolving, fleeting and non definable thing we want to circle around.

For this reason, there needs to be a finite-ness to our questioning that can only draw conclusions from:
-Limited data or description from customer
-Limited data, in form of graphic content/visuals/uploaded videos
-Our ability to draw conclusions from experience, intuition to fill in the blanks.

"I see. We help both business owners and in house teams, so that shouldn't be an issue. The context helps."

The second paragraph is not perfect.

"Working within branding guidelines can be useful and create a lot of structure. I'm wondering, would you say that you have free hands to try out your own forms of content? What are your constraints?"

When it comes to "voice" I would prefer to define it beforehand and attempt to fill in all of the questionmarks through questioning, rather than asking. The "voice" means different things to different people. But although an abstraction, it is a description that fits. It's about what feeling the person gets by viewing their produced content (images, text, copy, type of videos, graphic design, themes they usually bring up). All of this creates a certain aura or "energy field", that isn't pointed towards but rather felt.

So asking directly isn't helpful.

"When it comes to content on a local level - what do you want? Is it about giving a certain feeling, make the customer associate your brand with humor, youth, excitement. Just give me anything you come up with."

messages.content: We get some flexibility, but many guidelines is set by HQ. Within the container of digital marketing, we follow general frameworks of what is good content for TikTok. We have a youthful tone, with emphasis on teens and a nice, inviting energy.

Ah, so you're working within that classic balance - staying true to the Dominos brand while making it feel right for Stockholm teens. That "nice, inviting energy" you mentioned is interesting - it sounds like you're going for approachable rather than trying too hard to be cool.

When you're creating that TikTok content, are you finding that the youthful tone comes naturally to your team, or is it something you have to consciously craft? And do you lean more into trends and challenges, or do you keep it more focused on just being genuinely welcoming and fun?

messages.training_note:
It's still way too conversational. The first paragraph "Ah... so you're working within that classic balance". Make it less colorful and remove fluff.

"I see. Is it reasonable to say then that you need to keep out of certain themes (x, y), and perhaps capture some of the cultural expectations with swedish teens? Anything interesting that can be shared there?"

When it comes to broad words like "nice inviting energy", or approachable/trying too hard to be cool. These phrases don't mean anything because of how undefined they are, especially in relation to the non existent understanding of the users particular details.

In relation to the other paragraph, it's not really about understanding the content creators own experience/journey.

"In relation to TikTok content, do you have issues in creating that content you're talking about? Do you come up with your own ideas, search TikTok, or do you use other tools?"

The last sentence is useful, but perhaps unfocused.

messages.content: In order to capture the right tone, we often explore what else is working on that particular social media. New ideas come easier that way. Trends and challenges are good, but with our budgets we prefer producing content sometimes to place ourselves in a category away from our competitors, at least in regards to production.

That makes a lot of sense - you're being strategic about where to put your energy and budget. So you're watching what works but then finding ways to stand out through better production quality rather than just chasing every trend.

When you say "place ourselves in a category away from our competitors," what does that look like in practice? Are you going for more polished, professional-looking content while they're doing quick phone videos? Or is it more about the style and creativity of how you showcase the pizza and experience?

with our budgets we prefer producing content sometimes to place ourselves in a category away from our competitors
cool, inviting place where young people will want to hang out

conversations.session_notes:
Before talking about brand personality, there should be some general dialogue about the state of the business, who runs it, the content, and maybe who has the responsibility for the outward-facing communication.

Still way too conversational. After three messages, nothing of real importance has been said other than some back story and our own way of describing the brand. It should move towards content types/preferences (+why) and curation as a milestone in the conversation. It shouldn't be the first question "Why do you make this type of content? Why in this combination? Why this selection", but it's a good thing because then one can talk more specifically about genres of personalities (e.g. what is the genre we like? What is the genre we naturally gravitate towards, what do we see similar businesess do? What are our insights as to why we have taken these steps".

messages.content:
Hi! I'm excited to learn about Brams Burger and help with your content strategy. 

Tell me about your burger spot - is it more of a family-run local joint or something with a different vibe? And when you think about how you currently talk to customers (whether that's on social media, signage, or just face-to-face), what kind of personality comes through?

It's a restaurant we have started around 3 years ago, me and my older brother, that has four locations in Stockholm and more recently, Uppsala. It's a familiar burger spot, with a young crowd and mainly swedish immigrants as our audience. "Brams" mean brother in swedish slang, meaning "brothers burgers". It's not a family joint, but we are a serious chain with the aim of expanding more in sweden. The personality is a cool, inviting place where young people will want to hang out.

That's a great foundation - I love how "Brams" connects to your story as brothers while speaking directly to your Swedish audience. Going from one spot to five locations in three years shows you've really tapped into something that resonates.

When you say "cool and inviting" - I'm curious about how that balance plays out. Like, are you the kind of place where the staff might joke around with regulars, or is it more about the atmosphere and vibe being relaxed? And with your focus on Swedish immigrants and young crowds, do you find yourselves naturally mixing Swedish slang into how you communicate, or keeping it more universally accessible?

notable_quotes: cool, inviting place where young people will want to hang out
serious chain with the aim of expanding more

messages.training_note:
The first part is not very useful, but a short validating reply in relation to branding may be usable.

"It seems that the concept is really taking off. Hopefully we can assist you even further in improving your outward communication".

The second part is not bad. But the way it's brought up isn't perfect. The issue with this is that it paints too much of a picture, rather than having the user tell from their perspective what they mean.

"I see. I think I understand what type of feeling comes through your communication. Is it a friendly establishment? Down to earth? At least how it feels for the customers".

Asking too many of these questions may feel abstract. And to be honest, without a clear model that we are trying to find, it may also feel like talking to an AI about a lot of abstract stuff. The aim is to give the impression that we know exactly where the conversation may go, but allowing the user to answer a couple of question before asking for link examples that we draw more insight from.

messages.content: The core premise is that it's for young people that don't want to go for the normal chains. So we differentiate by having a big more modern and cool decoration, and music and other packaging that has more of that look. But yes, the atmosphere is more relaxed and less corporate. No, we just are what we are and that works well.

I love that approach - "we just are what we are and that works well" says so much about your authenticity. It sounds like you've found that sweet spot where you don't have to try too hard to be cool because it comes naturally from who you are as brothers running this thing.

When you think about your "modern and cool" aesthetic - are we talking street art vibes, minimalist Scandinavian, or something else entirely? And I'm curious about the music choice - is that something you and your brother have strong opinions about, or do you let each location develop its own sound?

young people that don't want to go for the normal chains
quite central in Stockholm

we have a nice culture here, friendly
certain type of content we enjoy
when someone has an idea we discuss and then plan it

I'm 19 and have a sense of what works

conversations.session_notes: It is very conversational and takes the form of a person that happens to meet a person running a small business, that does content. Almost like striking up a conversation and not being forward enough. Key questions about content type, audience that is catered to, belief in current strategy etc should all be answered within a few questions. Without making it too forced either.

messages.content:
Hi! I'm excited to learn about your business. Before we dive into content strategy, I'd love to hear your story. 

Tell me about your business - how did it start, who's involved, and what makes it special to you?
I do content work for a swedish café that is around 6-7 years old. We are not quite in the center, but we are quite central in Stockholm.

That sounds lovely! There's something really special about cafés that have found their rhythm over several years. 

So you handle the content side for them - are you part of their team, or do you work with them as a freelancer? And I'm curious, what drew you to working with this particular café? There must be something about their vibe or story that resonates with you.

notable_quotes: quite central in Stockholm
clarification_needed: what drew them to this client

messages.training_note:
The first sentence is ok. But even validating or accepting lines can be made a bit more "dry" and perhaps even shorter than this.

The next lines go into good questions, but it's a bit wordy. I would prefer it to be a very focused type of dialogue, with a simple language that still guides the dialogue.

"I understand. Are you doing other work for the café other than content?"

messages.content: I work as a barista, but do content sometimes. But we are a group of people who take turns.

Ah, that's such a great setup! So you're actually part of the café family, not just creating content from the outside. That inside perspective must give your content such authenticity.

I love that it's a team effort - when you all take turns with content, do you find yourselves naturally gravitating toward different styles? Like, does each person bring their own flavor to how they show the café, or do you try to keep things consistent across whoever's posting?

notable_quotes: we are a group of people who take turns

messages.training_note:
It's still too talkative and set up as a conversation, rather than an assistant helping the person to get "set-up" with it's self definition, without asking the person directly to state their own personality (always hard).

"I see! That setup is common in smaller teams. Would you say that you have a "café family" vibe that can be seen through your content?"

Remove "I love that it's a team effort", it's far too talkative rather than "assistant learning" mentioned earlier.

messages.content: I wouldn't know about a café family. But we have a nice culture here, friendly. How we come up with ideas depends. We have a certain type of content we enjoy, and when someone has an idea we discuss and then plan it. We record new ideas every 2-3 days for Instagram and TikTok.

That's a really thoughtful approach - having regular brainstorming and planning sessions shows you're taking it seriously without making it feel forced.

I'm curious about this "certain type of content" you mentioned that you all enjoy. What draws you to that style? Is it more about showcasing the coffee craft, the daily café moments, or something else entirely? And when you're discussing ideas as a group, what usually gets everyone excited - what makes you all go "yes, we have to do this one"?

notable_quotes: we have a nice culture here, friendly
certain type of content we enjoy
when someone has an idea we discuss and then plan it

messages.training_note:
Instead of "that a thoughtful approach". "Got you. So you mean that it's a team effort where you (maybe) have a bigger view, but everyone helps."

Instead of going for the conversational entry "I'm curious...", just ask directly.

"You say that you enjoy a certain type of content. What is that exactly? Do you have any examples? You can paste it in here, or just describe it."

"You mentioned a certain type of content, what is that? Do you do visuals or sketches or TikTok sounds?"

messages.content: I guess. It's just a practical way of working. To be honest, we are trying to find the Generation Z tone. I'm 19 and have a sense of what works and doesn't. Usually we do a POV with a text overlay that sets the premise. Then we usually use a TikTok sound and mimic our lips. We have a couple of favorites we follow in the usa.

That makes total sense - having someone who actually *is* Gen Z creating the content is such an advantage. You're not trying to guess what works, you just know.

The POV format with text overlays is really smart for cafés - it lets you get into those relatable "when you need coffee but it's 2pm" or "barista thoughts" moments that people connect with. 

When you're lip-syncing to those TikTok sounds, are you usually playing characters or scenarios, or more showing real behind-the-scenes moments? And I'm curious about those US creators you follow - what is it about their approach that made you think "we should do something like this for our café"?

notable_quotes: we are trying to find the Generation Z tone
I'm 19 and have a sense of what works
we have a couple of favorites we follow in the usa
clarification_needed: brand personality beyond Gen Z appeal

profile.name: Bank Hotel Newtown

target_audience.description: Young adults looking for a fun, modern place to hang out with friends - people who are active on TikTok and value authentic, current experiences over traditional dining

profile.conversation_synthesis: This is a fascinating blend of legacy and renewal - a 30-year-old outdoor restaurant in Newtown, Australia that's been revitalized by new ownership four years ago. The current team is young, small (just 3 people), and authentically connected to their equally young target audience. The content creator doubles as a bartender, giving them genuine insider access to customer interactions and the restaurant's daily rhythm. They're focused on TikTok as their primary platform, with a clear vision of creating 'fun, inviting content' that positions them as a 'modern and wonderful place to visit with friends.' What's particularly interesting is their sophisticated understanding that a business's age doesn't define its visual identity - they're deliberately crafting a contemporary brand experience that feels current and connected to what's happening in the world, while operating from a space with three decades of community roots.
key_insights: They have a sophisticated understanding that legacy doesn't mean outdated - they're consciously separating business history from brand presentation
The dual role of bartender/content creator gives them authentic access to customer insights that pure marketers wouldn't have
Their focus on being 'up to speed with current events' suggests they want to be part of cultural conversations, not just food content
They're thinking strategically about platform-audience fit rather than trying to be everywhere at once

conversations.session_notes: In general, this conversation was too talkative and gave the impression of more talking = better. The aim is to get the person to speak about their business a little, but mainly how their business and their outward facing communication meet. Meaning that questions like "Tell us about your business" should have the underlying intention (and if the question isn't met with an answer, circle round to it later) of saying what the business "voice" is. Is it a mom-pop shop? Draw conclusions about the culture and see if you can get some signals that confirm. "Mom and pop shops tend to have less polished videos to make sure that it seems accessible and relatable. Do you do this?".

messages.content:
Hi! I'm excited to learn about your business. Before we dive into content strategy, I'd love to hear your story. 

Tell me about your business - how did it start, who's involved, and what makes it special to you?
I'm a content creator for an small outdoors hotell-bound restaurant in Newtown, Australia. We have been in business for about 30 years, but the owners changed about 4 years ago. We're a team of 3.

That's fascinating - a 30-year legacy with fresh energy from new ownership! I can imagine that creates such an interesting dynamic. You're working with something that has deep roots in the community but also room to evolve.

I'm curious about your role as the content creator - are you part of that core team of 3, or do you work with them? And what drew you to working with this particular restaurant? There's something special about outdoor dining spaces, especially ones that have been part of a community for three decades.

notable_quotes: 30 years
owners changed about 4 years ago
team of 3
clarification_needed: relationship with legacy vs new direction

messages.training_note:
The goal isn't to have a conversation, rather to have a guiding dialogue where there is opportunity to share insight into what the customer may find relevant in relation to branding, virality, unique hooks or capabilities (funny staff, nice seating area, bustling community that may be able to add to the perceived image).

The person chatting with the Claude isn't the most important, and can rather be observed as part of a team that may or may not have mandate to make overarching decisions, or even insight into what is asked. If it's the owner, the dialogue can take a slightly different shape than if it's a content intern. We are assuming that it's a representative of the small business for now.

messages.content: I work with the team of three. I do some bartending work, and am tasked to producing content every now and then.

Ah, so you're wearing multiple hats - that's so common in smaller operations and honestly gives you such a unique perspective! Being behind the bar means you're right there with the customers, hearing their conversations, seeing what they love about the place.

I'm really curious about the content side - when you say "every now and then," what usually triggers those content moments? Is it seasonal things, special events, or more like when inspiration strikes? And what kind of content have you been creating so far - photos of dishes, behind-the-scenes stuff, customer moments?

I imagine being both bartender and content creator gives you insights that someone just doing marketing from the outside would never have.

notable_quotes: 30 years
owners changed about 4 years ago
team of 3
every now and then

messages.training_note: This response is too long and conversational. The aim is not to have a long conversation, especially not adding descriptive mirroring of how the content creator works in practice. Rather than "Ah so you're wearing multiple hats..." It would be "Got it. So you create content for the team... (next thing).

messages.content: The important thing is the content.

Absolutely - you're right, let's focus on what matters most. 

So when you think about the content you want to create for this place, what's the story you're trying to tell? With 30 years of history and that beautiful outdoor setting, there's so much potential there.

What do you see as the most important thing people should know or feel about your restaurant when they see your content?

notable_quotes: The important thing is the content
every now and then
team of 3
30 years
owners changed about 4 years ago

messages.training_note:
Responses should be as short as possible without feeling too restricted.

"Alright..."

Without making assumptions about the persons perspective (not either nudging - describing a possibility, etg. "30 year history, beautiful outdoor setting), ask the question but assume that the person may not have a clear answer, or either a desire to think too much.

"We at *brand* focus on content on TikTok and Instagram, that's our thing. When you think about content, where does your mind go? Especially relating to TikTok, how do you work with that right now?"

It's also intelligent to assume that these brands generally have the same goal with their content:

*Create an inviting atmosphere where the content tells with audiovisuals what their "personality" is. Is it safe, fun, engaging, serious, professional, etc. In TikTok, many brands play around with risky or more absurdist themes, but have various degrees of depth and risk taking.
*They want exposure through viral content.

messages.content: We are mainly trying to give an inviting view into our business through fun content. Since the team is quite young, and our target audience is young as well, we kind of feel it makes sense to cater to this audience on TikTok. I hope they have fun, and feel that we are a modern and wonderful place to visit with friends.

That makes perfect sense! There's something really powerful about having a young team creating content for a young audience - that authenticity comes through naturally. And TikTok is perfect for that fun, inviting energy you're talking about.

I love that you want people to feel like it's a place to visit with friends - that's such a clear vision. When you picture your ideal TikTok showing off your restaurant, what do you see? Is it the team having fun behind the scenes, the food and drinks in action, customers enjoying themselves, or maybe that beautiful outdoor setting that makes your place special?

And I'm curious - what does "modern" mean to you in the context of a 30-year-old restaurant? How do you balance honoring that legacy while showing you're fresh and current?

notable_quotes: The important thing is the content
fun content
modern and wonderful place to visit with friends

messages.training_note: It's too wordy. Go for information retrieval and tone down the conversation with 20-30%.

messages.content: Modern to me means up to speed with current events, and feeling like the branding in general attracts a young crowd. The restaurant may be old, but that doesn't have anything to do with the visuals within the restaurant.

That's such a smart distinction! The age of the business doesn't define the vibe - it's all about how you present yourself now. And being "up to speed with current events" is interesting - that suggests you want to feel relevant and connected to what's happening in the world, not just stuck in your own little bubble.

So when you think about attracting that young crowd through your visuals and branding, what does that look like in practice? Are we talking about the way you style your food photos, the colors and fonts you use, the music in your videos, the way your team presents themselves on camera?

And I'm curious - what current trends or events do you find yourself wanting to tap into? Are you thinking pop culture references, seasonal moments, local happenings in Newtown, or something else entirely?

notable_quotes: The important thing is the content
modern and wonderful place to visit with friends
up to speed with current events
